yaml.title: Machine Learning
yaml.subtitle: Understand Data | Fit Models | Test Performance
yaml.description: Learn the full modeling process — from data understanding and feature prep to model fitting and performance evaluation. This section emphasizes clarity, reproducibility, and metrics over magic.
yaml.navdesc: Learn the modeling process from data prep to model fitting and performance evaluation

markdown.markdown:
Machine learning isn’t magic — it’s a process. This section walks through the core workflow: exploring and shaping data, building and training models, and testing how well they perform. Expect practical tools, clear examples, and real evaluation — not black boxes or buzzwords. **It’s not the model — it’s what you do with it.** ::: {.callout icon="none" .custom-callout .go-further title="Projects > Parameters"} Don’t get stuck in a loop of adjusting sliders and chasing score decimals. Build projects. Focus on data (more data, cleaner data, feature engineering) for insight. Make something that solves a problem or tells a story. ::: - **Explorator Data Analysis (EDA)**: Understand data properties, data types, missing data, outliers, and more key factors to effective ML. - **Classification**: Models that work on categorized predictions (spam/not-spam). - **Regression**: Models that prediction continuous values (stock prices). - **Evaluation Metrics**: Determine how to evaluate a model and assess performance. Need a place to start? Check out the [FAQs](/machine-learning/faqs.qmd)!

Models & Metrics

What can ML do? → Overview of data and algorithms for ML
Random Forest (NB) → Deep dive into decision trees and random forest models

Classification

Iris Classification (NB) → Complete classification pipeline based on Iris dataset

Regression

Housing Regression (NB) → Complete regression pipeline based on housing dataset
::: {.callout icon="none" .custom-callout .d-bugz title="Chasing Scores, Missing Stories"} I used to run dozens of models, hyperparameter tuning, and comparitive metrics. While it taught me a lot, the biggest lesson was: Modeling is a tool, *meaning* is the goal. **Understand data** — no good models are built on bad data **Fit Models** — no good inference comes from inappropriate models **Test Performance** — all models are poor until proven otherwise :::
"I fear not the man who has practiced 10,000 kicks once, but I fear the man who has practiced one kick 10,000 times"— Bruce Lee
Machine learning isn't magic, and it’s not about finding the model — it’s about applying the right tools to meaningful questions. The most advanced models require on proper input and programming.
